p.s: The clever use of narrative technique and languelanguage allows the author to affect the readersreader's perception of Delaney state of mind.
The passage at hand is narrated by a third personthird-person narrator.
He is omniciantomniscient in terms of Delaney, he has access to his thoughts and therefore is able to tell the story in a more detailed and varied way for a witness for example could.
This knowledge allows him to let the reader get an impression of what Delaney is thinking.
He does that with the use of reported thought (e.g. ll. 1f, 25f, 35f).
The reader can use that information to get an ipression of how Delaney is feeling in the situation and it can also foreshadow actions that might follow later due to his thoughts.
Furthermore, the reader is given the opportunity to identify with the person based on his thoughts and feeling.
However, the passage is narrated by a third personthird-person narrator, the opportunity is minimized to the fact that a third personthird-person narrator creates a certain distance.
The reader also gets a great impression of the setting and the atmosphere influcences Delaney's state of mind because the author makes use of adjectives (ll. 19, 31, 45f).
In general, T. C. Boyle is able to create a scene, where you can put yourself in with detailed description of what is happening (ll. 9f, 37f, 40).
Moreover, he makes use of a climax which stresses DelaneysDelaney's anger and his general feeling of dissatisfaction and maybe even helplesness in the situation (l. 31).

To conclude, with the clever use of reported thought, adjective, detailed description in general and stylistic devices climax T. C. Boyle is able to affect the perception of Delaney's state of mind, which seems angry, unsatisfied and a little helpless.
